title: Will Nicolas Maduro cease to be president of Venezuela before 1 January 2021?

All carrot, no stick: Biden seeks negotiations with Venezuela's Maduro and his allies - WorldOil

https://www.dw.com/en/venezuelas-maduro-to-shut-all-powerful-legislative-assembly/a-55994728
Sat, 19 Dec 2020 05:21:08 GMT

For this question to be true I considered 3 scenario's that could happen: a coup, death, or voluntary resignation. 
The chance of an incumbent dying in office in a given year (Based on the last 20 years) is about 1,25%  (50 dead leaders over 20 years and +- 200 countries)
Change of a Coup in South America and the Caribbean the last 20 years was 0,8% ( 7 coups in 20 years over +-40 counties)
The same change in the previous century was around 2%. Since Venezuela's situation in my opinion resembles that of Latin America counties over the whole 20th century more closely than a Latin American country in the 21st century I raise the probability of a coup from 0,8% to 1,5%, closer to the 20th century average.
The change of a voluntary stepdown I consider too small to measure.
Adding the percentages up gives a change of Maduro not making 1-1-2021 at 2,75%. Since there are only 15 Days left in this year this gives an probability of around 0.1%. I round this up to 1% - never ascribe zero possibility.

Venezuela's opposition concludes 'popular consultation' to reject Maduro - Reuters

Sat, 12 Dec 2020 22:21:00 GMT Thin. Very thin
Time passing. True probability rounds to 0%.
The Odds of him catching a freedom pellet increase proportionately, with the approach of transitions that may or may not occur.
WIth so little time left of the year and so little noise from Venezuela I'm going down to 0% for the last weeks of the year.  Yes: -4
b4 20Jan., 2021 the same year that the original Mad Maz movie was set in. Watch for fleet movements and Russia reinforcements.

the chances of a change this late in the game are under half a percent.

Madura age 58.  
Status Quo = Maduro Stays in Power Dies: Average life expectancy in Venezuala is 72.25 years.  Increase that for maduro since he has access to well above average health care. in the US a 58 yr old male has a .98% chance of dying within one year (social security actuarial table)
https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
- Slightly higher risk with COVID, he's approaching the riskier age groups
we'll double the US risk from .98 to 2% chance of dying within a year, and double again for COVID to 4%, then divide in 1/6 for the two months out of 12, giving us .67% chance of dying of natural causes before January (round up to 1%). Removed by the US: 9 acknowledged successful US backed coups in Latin America since 1954.
https://apnews.com/article/2ded14659982426c9b2552827734be83
- Slightly higher chance due to Lame Duck moves by President Trump removing defense officials who had objected to his policy goals.
1% Removed by his own country or opposition: Unlikely, he has increased control due to covid and continued to consolidate his allies in power. 1%
https://www.npr.org/2020/07/28/896261268/venezuelas-maduro-holds-firmly-to-power-and-squeezes-the-opposition

Venezuela to Discuss Dollarization Plan With Local Banks
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-16/venezuela-is-said-to-discuss-dollarization-plan-with-local-banks
This is huge.
~1% risk of death + ~1% risk of upheaval

Remote chance. Based on support from external actors and intent to hold on to power regardless of internal/external pressure over the past few years. Lack of threat to the regime from foreign powers I.e. the US.
Not a chance. He is a dictator and will not leave the presidency

Elections will not be free or fair. Things that change my mind:
-Covid measures create civil unrest within the country
-He dies
-Economy collapses
-Military coup Overall, China's influence will aid in thwarting the latter two cases.  COVID may cause unrest, but previous situations have not resulted in removal.
Maduro isn't going anywhere and I don't think the US will take any additional actions before January 1, 2021.

Maduro and his administration has stayed in office during the passive aggressive Obama administration as well as with the openly aggressive Trump administration. The Biden administration is looking to overcompensate their geopolitical ties
Unlikely but perhaps Trump wants to go out with a flourish.
Unlikely, as he has not given up with all he stuff that has happened in the past. With 57 he is also not very likely to be severely impacted by Covid.

Not likely since his grip on power is too strong. Unless covid19 destroys all the economy and his associates blame him.
No, Maduro will not be forced from office this year He is a functioning dictator. His opposition has fallen by the wayside.
There aren't many indications that Maduro's regime is in any immediate danger. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKBN26U01T
Regime will hold on and no one is really interested in pushing him out.
Risk increased slightly in light of the growing uncertainty about the elections in Venezuela. Then it increased a bit more when Trump started running out of tricks to win the US election

Nope.  Not a chance. He's pretty dug into power even with the instability and international pressure.  It hasn't done anything yet.  No reason to suspect something will happen in the closing months of 2020.
Unless the news is completely inaccurate it's unlikely that the military will denounce him before this date.
He might die of natural causes but he won’t be removed from power
He's firmly in charge, despite economic challenges

The regime in Caracas is completely entrenched. The Cuban intelligence services, which are among the most skilled at state sponsored repression in the world, are in the country in large numbers suppressing dissent and sowing chaos within the disparate factions of the opposition. Furthermore most Venezuelans left in the country are either true believers or wholly dependent on the regime for basic needs, leading them to support the regime.

Base line: 90%. No president has been sitting more than 5 years since 1958 and Maduro has now been in office for 7 years. 
- Since the 2009 constitutional referendum, any person can be elected to the office an indefinite number of times and sits 6 years each term Probability of his death - 2%
- Maduro is 58 years old and life expectancy for men his age is 78 (https://www.worldlifeexpectancy.com/country-health-profile/venezuela). Most common cause of death is heart disease I since I have found no information about health issues I will rate this as the average 2% likelihood of him dying Probability of resignation - 0%
- Given him staying in power, after the 7 years it looks like he is not likely to voluntarily resign so I rate this within the given period as 0%. Probability of removal - 1%
- Mounting pressure internationally would make this the most likely driver of change. According to the Dictators Handbook (https://www.amazon.com/Dictators-Handbook-Behavior-Almost-Politics/dp/1610391845) as long as the supporters inc. the military can be paid off it is unlikely that removal is likely. The economy seems to be in dire straits (https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/venezuela-economy-facts-2019-5-1028225117?op=1#) but I assume the oil money would still be more than sufficient to pay off the people needing to be payed off. 
- the US does not support Maduro, one might speculate because it want to get its hands on the oil but with China and Russia on the other end it seems to balance out.
Not with Russia and China backing him.
The US will be main driver of his removal. US will be focused on national elections and replacing a Supreme Court Justice and not be able to focus on Venezuela.

It depends on what China and Russia want, for Maduro govt is a perfect moment to leave with minors consequences, because until now China and Russia were pushing Maduro and his staff to stay in the govt. If they clever is the perfect moment to leave. For first time it's really depending on them what to do, leave with minor consequencies or stay and pray for a china winning the globe.

Sample size insufficient to determine an average term length for authoritarian dictators in Venezuela. 
Release of Political prisoners indicates a period of relative stability.
Economic growth shows signs to have flattened, withstanding the impacts of US sanctions.

"sanctions on Venezuela have been ineffective in generating the regime change U.S. officials want. Twenty months after the decision by the United States and a large number of European and Latin American nations to recognize Juan Guaidó as interim president of Venezuela, Maduro is, if anything, even more deeply entrenched in power." https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/09/17/iran-teaching-venezuela-maduro-how-to-withstand-us-sanctions/

The arrest of a US citizen can go in all sorts of directions, but it's not enough for me to consider moving the needle and normally doesn't result in the toppling of a government. Although its worth keeping an eye out to see if this is enough see if this is the straw that breaks the camels back so to speak. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/09/venezuela-captured-spy-sought-sabotage-power-grid-200914190535286.html
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages. Actually I'm not staying steady.
I'm Increasing my very low probabilities for other questions a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.But I'm staying steady on this one.

Maduro has demonstrated his ability to put down a coup before, and while there is still instability within the country (gas shortages etc.) Maduro has also released a lot of political prisoners recently which makes me think he feels rather secure in his position, at least for the next three and a half months. I think his opponents simply need more time if they expect to remove him forcefully.
The world is too busy dealing with Covid-19 and the related economic slow to bother with a minor dictator Maduro.

"U.S. sanctions targeting Venezuela’s oil industry have slashed Caracas’ crude exports to the lowest in decades, but they have failed to loosen Maduro’s grip on power - something that has frustrated President Donald Trump, officials say." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-usa-venezuela/pompeo-to-visit-brazil-border-as-u-s-ramps-up-pressure-on-maduro-idUSKBN2663CC

Revising slightly upward — "Venezuela's Guaido calls for more international pressure on Maduro" https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics/venezuelas-guaido-calls-for-more-international-pressure-on-maduro-idUSKBN25Y24M

Situation seem stable. The time around the december election will probably be a deciding factor. There might be mass protests before and after the election... and there might be nothing. And even if there is protests that of course doesn't mean a political change of power is a given.  Yes: -1

There have been few signs of Venezuela's military joining the opposition, and Maduro has used a number of "coup-proofing" techniques to ensure that even if some do, there are others who will still support him. This includes patronage, overlapping military services, and personally loyal militia type groups. While some research suggests that competitive militaries may in fact further the likelihood of military units sitting out a coup, it is also likely to ensure some dissention between military officers. International intervention also seems unlikely, although the lack of support from friendly regimes like Russia does appear negative.
Going half way with the crowd.
Use of state violence; weak and divided opposition
Chances are very low. Nothing is changed for 3 years now and likely to stay so. There might be a plot rising but not before the election in US and the new presidency later 2021.

The US has resumed some aid to Venezuela in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, and the CPI in Venezuela has not grown nearly as much in the past year as in the preceding year, both of which suggest that unrest will not grow enough to prevent Maduro from holding onto power into next year. Furthermore it seems that we may have passed the zenith of international pressure on Maduro, whose legimitacy as president has been questioned for many months now without him being removed from office.

Time slot is small
Military unlikely to intervene due to Madura has been incentivising them to stay loyal Could see the counter point of covid19 leading to a surge to coup to stabilise currency and get healthcare aid but think that is unlikely

Technically, he is no longer the president, but you need to let him know that, even after all the international pressure I don't see him acknowledging a defeat so under his terms he is and will remain being the president

Nonetheless, with mounting external and internal pressure, I believe there is some possibility of a collapse.
unlikely he will cease to be president if he and his keys to power remain healthy, but covid is a wildcard.

Raising my estimate 4 percentage points as Maduro is likely to get coronavirus since it is ripping through is regime[1]. Less than 1% chance he gets it and dies, but if he becomes seriously ill it could create a power vacuum and an opportunity for secret rivals within his administration. If he is in power at the end of September, I will probably drop my estimate for this question to 0%.
[1] https://www.manisteenews.com/news/article/Close-adviser-to-Venezuela-s-president-has-15480023.php

"the pandemic has taken hold in the country ... As hospitals get overrun and confidence in government collapses, Venezuela is bracing for chaos ... But President Nicolás Maduro has been treating this crisis as an opportunity, steadily strengthening his grip on power ahead of this year’s parliamentary elections ... in recent weeks, Maduro has managed to strengthen his grip on the country’s institutions and political parties. In mid-June, Venezuela’s top court—which remains loyal to Maduro—ousted the leaders of two major opposition parties, replacing them with chavista loyalists. In early July a similar move suspended the leadership of Voluntad Popular, the former party of Guaidó." https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/08/10/coronavirus-maduro-consolidating-control-venezuela/
This is a bad time for revolution.  I give it a 1% that he dies.
Already weakened, he's likely to lose control after the actual economic crisis hit in late 2020

I see nothing to indicate that Maduro’s hold on power has weakened. Legislative elections are slated for December 6th, and while they will likely be fraudulent, I do not foresee it leading to Madura being removed from office between that date and 12/31.
He was already a president for a long time

Going down. I deem my previous forecast was to high to begin with and with less time go I would lower my forecast anyway. 
Right now oil prices seem pretty stable. There is an economic crisis in Venezuela and it's still a pretty unstable country. I do find it likely there will be social protests in the coming months in Venezuela, but to me it seem Guaidó has gone from someone who can rally support for the opposition to more of a burden who make people turn away.

Nicolas Maduro is consolidating power [1, 2] — he is much more secure in his position relative to a few months ago. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics/venezuelas-major-opposition-parties-pledge-to-boycott-december-election-idUSKBN24Y0ME

same as last time, I think international focus on this issue won't return until next year.

Chance is very unlikely a dictator could be removed from his office. He’s in control in all aspect, his competitor Guaido doesnt have enough power and military coup has failed to upend Maduro. Only external powers can flip the situation but currently they’re busy with other things.

Very few in US or the world cares in making this priority and it is not politically advantageous to continue to hit a nation's head against the wall in this issue or raise military funding or troops in an economic malaise or social unrest world. It anything, will return to the issue next year.
The power transition in itself is not a very rare event especially in Latin America. The probability is boosted by the upcoming elections in December, however lowered by the COVID-19 pandemic.

The response here is similar to the question concerning Juan Gusaido and his threat to Maduro.
Maduro has managed to weather the International pressure and Gusaido where the latter peaked in his popularity earlier in the year.
The onset of the Covid-19 pandemic has forged a joint effort by Maduro and Gusaido to raise funds to fight the disease due to the refusal by the IMF to offer funds given the instability of the Presidency.
Therefore, Maduro will probably last until 1 January 2021. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-analysis/disappointed-venezuelans-lose-patience-with-guaido-as-maduro-hangs-on-idUSKCN1TW3ME
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics/venezuela-top-court-ousts-leaders-of-guaidos-party-ahead-of-vote-idUSKBN24833G
https://www.dailysabah.com/world/americas/venezuelas-maduro-guaido-agree-to-join-forces-in-covid-19-fight

https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/imf-rules-out-covid-19-loan-to-venezuela/1770442
The longer Maduro stays in power, the easier it will be to stay in power. Covid-19 has likely put outside intervention on hold at least until the sometime next year.

Given the COIVD situation there is significantly less international focus on the situation in Venezuela. The US are in the midst of their own election, the EU is dealing with the pandemic and Brexit.
It is likely elections will be delayed in December.
The possibility of a rebellion/coup seem less likely than perhaps 6-9 months ago, but never say never.
The US is usually the weight beind it, but there is not much foreign policy.

While in the election year, unlikely that the US administration would risk a direct foreign intervention especially in the face of a global pandemic. However, small probability exists of rebellion against Maduro with some external help.
Still has enough insight to remain in control
Lowering slightly due to pandemic considerations that US and Venezuela have at present.
Too many other concerns for global leaders to take any significant action to move him along. He's stuck there through so much, it won't change now.
Very unpopular in general, but keeps the army loyal.
The country has already a weak economy and keeps suffering weakness  in an important scale.  There is not a concensus of removing him but ones it turns out it can happen quite easily.

He is a bit out of the headlines due to the crisis situation, also in other South American countries, particularly Brasil. This will soften international pressure. Domestically, I don’t think the army turns against him that shortly.
There is no longer a viable opposition

This one is simple, the only reasons for Maduro to leave office are death or military upheaval.  The probability of death in a 57 year old is 1%/year, or 1/2% by 2021.  I multiplied by 10 to include assassination, which is the source of the estimate.  There is no chance of outside (US) military, and no chance of Venezuelan military abandoning Maduro.  The military has it's issues, but they are loyal to Maduro and fare "reasonably well" in this difficult time.  Of course they're the likely assassins, but this is already included in the death estimate.
Maduro will continue to cling to power, ousting his detractors and installing friends in powerful offices.
5 months left; reduce by 1% every month.
Friends in Brazil paint a picture of an in increasingly violated and frustrated populace whose tolerance is near its end.

i read the damn question wrong... pandemic and unrest put a lot of pressure on him. outside support helps dampen that pressure. In run up to the election tensions could rise as Trump uses Venezuela as a foil.
I am going to soft round numbers for this forecast.
He may get COVID-19 and be unable to fulfill his duties.

very unlikely, probably something like four-fifths of a percent, so rounding up to 1%, but will probably drop it to 0% some time in October when, excluding any unlikely events, the probability falls below half a percent.

If the Joe Biden is elected, the US will have more important things to worry about than Venezuelan Politics. ALso I dont think with the state of the COVID situation that Venezuelan people will be willing to try to overthrow the government
Unlikely to happen with all the uncertainty surrounding COVID-19 and other countries, such as the US focused on the virus and internal politics.

Depends on the overall mood of Venezuelains.  With the upcoming US election and a win for Trump, combined with a Covid19 vaccine, and an increase the overall cabin fever feeling of the people we could see an overall mood change in the country against him.  If we dont see those three factors before January happen all at once it would be more likely that we see a similar fate as Syria.

With less than 6 months left of the year, and the ongoing pandemic swallowing vast amounts of time and energy I can see the more strategic players waiting out the crisis. Any new government would want to start with a display of positivity, and allowing the pandemic to play out first would be set the stage for a coup (etc) afterwards, uniting the people in a new way forward...
Too much in the world right now to worry about Nicola Maduro. Health is more important. Might change over time. For now 0%
Maduro controls the military. He will remain in power unless US intervenes
Not going to happen unless a surprise event occurs.
The covid situation is going to aggravate problems and destabilise economy further. Social unrest will increase even more.
Mis-read the question!  Changing forecast accordingly.
Things have been extremely bad for a long time but it appears to be much more difficult to shift him than previously thought.  Hard to see what on the horizon could shift this.
He's heavily consolidating power, but who knows if this will backfire.

Likely would require external influence to happen, yet with attention on COVID this reduces the likelihood.  Internal opposition is likely looking for external support reducing the chances the chances further with the above.
Very unlikely without major external intervention.

I don’t think he is on the way out, since the momentum is gone for ousting him. The world powers, including the US, will be preoccupied combatting the coronavirus, and he can do whatever he wants in the shade of that.
he still has the military behind him, social unrest might increase, but he will continue to be the president
Strong position but economic instability underpriced

- Bottom Line - other 21st Century dictators - how long in power before losing power, stepping back etc. 
- Focus of US is on Corona and 2020 Election
- Big protests already failed
- Opposition getting less unified

I just can't see the military deserting Maduro, particularly during a pandemic.  The wild card would be the overall chaos that the pandemic might bring to a country where public services are degraded and national cohesion is low.

"Venezuela election council sets parliament vote for Dec 6 [2020]" https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-election/venezuela-election-council-sets-parliament-vote-for-dec-6-idUSKBN2427FX Article "UK court rejects Maduro’s claim on $1bn of Venezuelan gold held by Bank of England" by FT (02 July 2020)
"A British court has dealt a blow to attempts by Nicolás Maduro’s regime to access $1bn of Venezuelan gold held at the Bank of England by ruling that opposition leader Juan Guaidó had been “unequivocally” recognised as Venezuela’s president by the UK." Article "How Venezuela’s regime plans to win this year’s legislative election", The Economist, 27 June 2020 Edition
"It shows, too, the regime’s craving for legitimacy. Mr Maduro’s belief in his right to rule comes in part from the status he claims as the heir of the late Hugo Chávez, the regime’s founder (pictured, far left) and, less plausibly, Simón Bolívar, Venezuela’s liberator (centre). He also wants the affirmation that comes from a popular mandate, even though just 13% of Venezuelans back the regime, according to Datanálisis, a polling firm."
https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2020/06/27/how-venezuelas-regime-plans-to-win-this-years-legislative-election If Maduro will not be torn down from his chair before December 2020 by his (very angry) people, then he will likely be voted down on 06 December 2020.
Coups probably not as common as I initially thought

Despite instability, Maduro shows that he still can control the army quite well. A lot of people decide to emigrate, and not to fight his regime. Covid crisis should also help him, because the most vulnerable people wouldn't fight him.
no , he does not want to be ousted , so he will not instigate a responce from the USA
Pandemic survivors will string him up.

Maduro holds a lot of control over the Venezuelan Presidency, Courts, and the Military. He is not particularly old nor have there been very many, possibly zero, legitimate assassination attempts against him. Frequent Purges and using the courts to seize/puppet opposition political parties (although not the main one, led by Guaido) mean he is unlikely to face revolutions from inside the Venezuela.
There is also very little political appetite for invasions / externally supported coups outside of Venezuela. With the US, SA, and EU mostly on the side of Guaido, and Russia, China, and the Middle East mostly backing Maduro's Regime. It is fairly unlikely that any states against Maduro will risk the Ire of the World Powers backing him.
The Wild Card however, is that Trump has an election coming up and may see an invasion/intervention in Venezuela as a good way to wag the dog (like he did with Soleimani and the Impeachment trial). On the other hand, Trump does seem to be warming up to Maduro (at the manipulation of Putin)

Sars-Cov-2 has eliminated all energy to fight for a change of political system at Venezuela. All international pressure up-to-now has nothing changed. Maduro remained in power till now. I think the situation remains stable until SARS-Cov-2 pandemic will has been finished by drugs or vaccines.

Trump has indicated that he likes Maduro now, so it's extremely unlikely the US will overthrow him: 
https://www.axios.com/trump-venezuela-guaido-maduro-ea665367-b088-4900-8d73-c8fb50d96845.html If President Biden wants to return the US to warmongering, Venezuela is a natural target, but it won't happen by the deadline.
Nothing on the horizion appears to change the status quo.
There is no one in power yet, not even stupider than Trump to upset global order.

- No credible opposition (only likelihood is military coup)
- US will not interfere for rest of year (elections)
- Age in favour, no known health issues

Maduro is significantly less liked (and approved of) internationally than his opposition, but has too strong of a hold on the military. Any attempt, outside of full blown internationally backed war, to replace him with Guaido would fail, as the several since 2018 have. Trump is not competent enough in diplomacy to convince him to step down. No other countries seem to either be in the position to or care to go to the negotiating table with Maduro. The only party willing and able to negotiate with Maduro is Guaido himself, but he was mostly unsuccessful in these attempts in 2019. Maduro does not seem to be willing to negotiate any longer with
Maduro is still far too supported by international leaders, but as Covid-19 takes grip, I could see the military losing faith and launching a coup.

What are some ways Maduro could leave office? (1) Voluntarily resigns
(2) Deposed by a military coup
(3) Deposed by a foreign military invasion (e.g. American)
(4) Beaten in an election, which he then accepts and steps down voluntarily
(5) Killed in office I think that about covers it. A review of the evidence leads me to think that the collective chances of (1), (3), and (4) are vanishingly small-- say 2% total. That leaves assassination and a military coup. The success of either depends on the loyalty of Venezuela's security forces. It seems like in normal economic conditions, generals' loyalty is essentially bought (https://www.occrp.org/en/revolution-to-riches/how-venezuela-bought-military-loyalty) and that a "proliferation of flag officers" creates conditions too fragmented for a coup (https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/venezuela-military/). Still- let's say there's 10% odds of a coup this year, and another 2% odds of assassination.
Trumps desire to meet with Maduro
6 months left; reduce by 1% every month.

Maduro currently has lots of power with little international pressure to resign. The pandemic as well as the US's domestic as well as potential international troubles (such as Israel increasingly likely annexation and oil prices) will leave little pressure from the main push from the country most involved in attempting to bring him down. Additionally if Biden becomes president that likelihood becomes even less likely as Trump made Maduro a main campaign topic. In relation to domestic troubles Juan Guido has lost his momentum. The citizens are tired and don't believe he will be brought down. The return of many citizens from Colombia additionally complicates things in which discourages opposition as things don't seem better elsewhere. The most stable country currently (China) has given him full support and it is hard to imagine a scenario in which China either becomes unstable or that it abandons Maduro.
Transfer of power would likely only happen due to a significant shift in support within the military.

There's a humanitarian and a political crisis in Venezuela, which is causing tension on a global scale, as well as a national scale for their country. Unfortunately, the failed paramilitary operation has put Guaido (Maduro's competition and the interim president) in a precarious position. It has also prompted Maduro to do more to ensure he stays in power. These are conflicts that will likely increase in intensity over the next year or so until they come to a head. They'll also likely affect relations between other countries even more. Despite this, it's unlikely all of this will come to a head and Maduro will be completely removed as Venezuela's president within the next six months.

Nicolás Maduro is feeling an incredible amount of pressure from his creditors and the Venezuelan population, but since receiving economic guidance and assistance from China, Russia and Iran, and since witnessing the mass Venezuelan exodus into Columbia and beyond, he can actually comfort in the Russian/Chinese/Iran need of an oil rich Western Hem ally, and the general mentality of Venezuelans, who’d rather leave than risk life for revolution. The government is a quasi stratocracy, which was manifested in the Punto Fijo Act of 1958.  The military at the time was willing to approve the transition into a democratic system in exchange for higher soldier and officer wages along with updated armaments. That moment created a mild symbiosis between military and state which Hugo Chavez sought to embolden.  Fast forward a few decades and the military is fully integrated.  Chavez handpicked successor has all the needed military support to ensure an American coordinated Allende or Goulart style coup d’etat will not occur.  Though Nic Maduro was only a bus driver, he has the faith of 2000 officers overseeing 150000 soldiers. An extreme number of officers spreads the possibility of dissent across a convoluted and intentionally messy bureaucratic field. The Supreme Tribunal of Justice is taking steps to disempower the National Assembly, removing any and all hardliners including the presidential pariah Juan Guaidó. At the end of the year is an expected election for the Constituent Assembly, and that could be an opportunity for a secondary political revolt led by Guaidó, another chance to execute a stronger strategy than the quickly squashed Bay of Caracas protest last year.   Unless the military turns on Maduro in the next 6 months, or a few thousand armed paramilitary Venezuelans coordinate an attack, Maduro will maintain his power and retain his featherbed high military support whether the population is decimated or not.  He will barter dirty oil with Turkey, Iran and others to keep the CLAP program hanging by a thread.
He has the support of Russia
pandemic leads to collapse of healthcare system and other basic services, widespread starvation and economic ruin leads to violent riots, the people remove him.
Not enough political support to remove him.

Maduro has maintained an iron grip. This now includes controlling the largest opposition parties.
(https://www.wsj.com/articles/venezuelas-maduro-takes-over-rival-political-parties-11592348738)

External military intervention is unlikely. There is always the possibility of a popular uprising but, right now, with the opposition in disarray and COVID-19 complicating things, it is, unfortunately, unlikely to happen this year.
Little chance an entity will prevent him from continuing.

There is no genuine organized force capable of challenging Maduro's hold on power. He would have to foresee and believe he was in trouble to exit. And his country is starving to death and troubled. The exercise of raw power has trained the population to accept the unacceptable. Not likely. But he's so awful, not impossible.
Cutting my forecast in half. With the oil price rising, one pressure point may be reduced.
There are too many intrenched interests in Venezuela keeping him in a leadership role
Regime change in Venezuela is a rare event

Given other events - the global pandemic, the panning of the oil market, and the botched attempts that have gone before us in terms of attempting to remove Maduro, it would seem unlikely that there will be sufficient momentum and political will to manufacture manufacture his removal. I question the level of appetite internally for further upheaval too. Interventions by Iran and Russia have linked Maduro’s fate to bigger events and questions, raising the prospect of his prolonged survival - it would seem unlikely that the USA would assess the value of bringing him down to be worth the potential costs against their other interests elsewhere. For now, he survives.

Maduro is unlikely to go absent significantly greater pressure from Donald Trump.  In general, given the distractions of COVID-19, George Floyd, and whatever comes next, this seems like a low probability event.  The upward pressure on probability will come from Trump's need to seize headlines/distract voters as the election nears.
Covid is compounding the economic situation there however there doesn't currently seem to be any effective opposition Military or political to force him out

Unless we face a big time intervention from foreign powers, especially US, Maduto still holds power enought to curb any attempt of change in the political scenario. The chance of an US intervention, given the internal turmoil, is low.
Too much happening in the globe to put together a coup to topple current govt.

Maduro has powerful allies. Russia will keep Maduro in power until they decide otherwise. Unless Maduro succumbs to an unforeseen medical complication, he will remain president of Venezuela indefinately.

Strong men presidents normally have mapped out multiple scenarios for their ouster and ways to survive them.
The 10% probability that he may be ousted is if Trump tried to stage a coup to bolster his own base with a presidential strong man action, which in Trump's mind will show him to be a string leader.

Maduro has held on to power for more than a year, despite significant pressure from the international community. It is unlikely that a more coordinated or concerted international effort to remove the Maduro administration will emerge in the next six months due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the same events that alleviate international pressure on Maduro also undercut the likelihood of international support from partners like Russia or Iran and make the administration more vulnerable to domestic pressures. At present, the Maduro administration with the help of law enforcement and the Venezuelan military appears capable of holding onto power. But an increasing COVID-19 death toll, and the attendant disorganization to government institutions dealing with the virus in their ranks, could quickly leave the Maduro administration teetering and a well-organized revolutionary movement might well be able to seize the opportunity.
It’s not easy to overthrow a western government.
It took Death to oust his predecessor, Hugo Chavez. I don’t think he will die before then.

Purely a political US decision. However, there are many other areas that could actively involve the US.  Unless an unusual opportunity offers itself the current administration should find it advantageous to keep its powder dry in order to engage in other, more aggressive, global areas.

COVID-19 has proved enough of a distraction for other countries to put more pressure on Venezuela. The country is a mess, but as long as the military stands by Maduro and Russia/Iran props him up, he will hang on for now.
Maduro is still popular with the military because he takes care of them financially.  So they will keep him in power for now.
Financial strain due to oil production/value. Waning media control with directv leaving country and lack of telecom infrastructure to replace.
World has too many other problems
The time has come for change.
The military is too invested in staying in power as well so Maduro will retain their support.

The greatest threat to Maduro would probably be widespread dissatisfaction combined with a public health crisis due to covid-19. Right now, Venezuela has fairly low numbers of reported cases and deaths, but I'd guess there is a small chance that will substantially change (either a rise in cases, or a rise in reported cases). Normally, the economic problems associated with the global public health crisis would also increase Maduro's chance of being forced out of office, but the economic situation in Venezuela is already dire, and that is unlikely to change. There is also a very small chance that Maduro will die or have serious health problems, but he is fairly young, so that chance is not significant.

Maduro, like other autocratic dictators possesses a stranglehold on his country’s rule. While a few months ago I would have predicted his downfall by EOY, I believe the COVID-19 pandemic will contribute to reduced levels of civic participation in Venezuela as well as less likely international engagement in trans-oceanic incidents. This will lead to Maduro most likely remaining in power through the end of 2020.

COVID will probably distract people from addressing internal societal challenges in Venezuela. Also the recent support from Iran will give a lifeline to the existing government. Since the US allowed the delivery of refined materials to Venezuela there are no other policing agencies to stop this support. Russia will not be helping any more until late in 2021 when their COVID situation comes under control and their first priority will probably be destabilizing Germany as the economic winner of the debt in Europe.

Developing countries won’t be able to stop the coronavirus and that’ll give the US and upper hand to be able to impose restrictions on Iran and China cutting off support. Banks have also began cutting off Venezuela’s citizens access to money transferring services like Zeele.
Barring outside intervention, see the USA, he will continue as president.  It is unlikely that any country in South America will intervene.
There don't appear to be opposition in positions of power inside or outside government
because there doesn't appear to be significant opposition
Covid-19 epidemic has the world distracted & strongman able to hold onto power
Things rarely change in third world : he has Russian backing .   Pandemic as a Crisis has distracted rebellion
With the current political climate and issues with the COVID 19 outbreak in South America I believe  Nicolas Madura will continue to be president of Venezuela until the end of 2020
Coronavirus outbreak will temporarily distract people with few resources to begin with, from making meaningful political changes of any sort until well into 2021.
With the rate of COVID disruptions, I feel like the push to get him out has taken a backseat.
While I feel it’s unlikely, there are possible internal and external pressures, including foreign involvement which keep me from going lower.

The only two governments that would get involved with Venezuela are Russia and the U.S. - and well, Russia obviously wants Maduro in office. The Trump Administration, even if they do publicly support Guaido, doesn't seem to interested in the situation. And if the recent failed coup attempt by the weird security group is any indication of the level of asshattery - I think it's safe to say he'll hold on to power for as long as we have Trump in office.

Dictators are seldom removed from power through protests or international shaming. They are not removed through brutal force either by a military coup or an outside country invading and deposing them.
No country will take the steps necessary to remove him from power unless his transgressions make it impossible yo let him remain in power. Unlikely to change near term.
Cutting forecast in half as no meaningful change is afoot.

There is no internal, organized opposition to Maduro due to mass emigration for a lack of food and necessities.  The military at this time appears to strongly support Maduro as well.  Externally, there is no coordinated effort to apply pressure from other nations or seek change due to COVID and concerns of possible recessionary trends.  The looming COVID crisis in Brazil will overshadow the question of Maduro.  Maduro also has support from Russia.
He probably has a 95% base-rate chance of continuing, but there is substantial coronavirus tail-risk.
Control of the military remains strong and the world is too distracted to focus on Maduro.

There isn't enough social pressure and internal turmoil to indicate a high likelihood that Maduro will be ousted.  The counter pressures of the COVID virus tends to bolster the behavior of a strongman, an apparent leader of strength in a time of uncertainty.

Too early to tell. While the turmoil isn't just about food (equality, freedom etc) the population is now seeing their food supplies dwindle and famine is a potential outcome.  If famine does hit the country and the rainy season (+oil access) can't support the needed crop growth, we will see the consequences before January 2021. While there may not be a complete regime change Maduro may be deposed.

If Silver Corp were to succeed in their missions then he could be removed and extradited. It is unlikely that they will succeed in any future mission. The possibility of a coup is extremely limited because political opponents to his regime have already been implicated in the SilverCorp mission in May. The sheer amount of high ranking Venezuelan military officers also makes the likelihood of a military coup lower because there are many people who are beholden to Maduro and they are less able to organize in resistance.
Only if violence is involved (or he dies of a disease).
The world is focused on Covid and BLM. The  US election is looming.  Latin America is becoming a hit spot for Covid.  January isn’t far away.  I don’t think it will get enough attention

US is the only power in the world that can & would want to knock Maduro off power, and there is just way too many things going on right now. Maduro can rest assured until after the elections in US. If Trump wins again, then there is an outside chance he'll start something, but very little possibility of results before 1 Jan 2021

Maduro appears to still have a decent control of the military, and a lack of concern for citizen grievances. The two combined mean he is unlikely to be ousted internally. Given COVID, American presidential elections, and general civil unrest in much of the western world, concrete actions from outside of Venezuela are also unlikely. Low oil prices, however, will continue to exert fiscal challenges to Maduro’s power and may cause defections from the military, but only if there is a clearly superior alternative.

It will likely take military intervention from other governments to remove him from office, and there doesn't appear to be a strong coalition for that move, especially in light of the global pandemic and US election. 5% given for potential health-related issues, such as contraction of coronavirus with subsequent death.

Recent failed coup attempts will make future ones unlikely. The coronavirus crisis and the blm protests will continue to divert the attention of the international community and also weaken some of his most powerful adversaries such as bolsonaro and trump.
Maduro is a dictator so he will stay in power through use of force.
The pressure in both the political sense and wider national sense is coming to a critical point
Continuing Chinese, Russian, and even Iranian support, barring a major internal event, means that Maduro will stay in power
He is securely supported by Russia and there is no viable opposition at this time. Also, Biden will not seek to oust him.

It is possible that continuing coronavirus instability and a second price crash in oil might lead to an overthrow of the government or an internal coup d' etat, but he has survived before and the opposition does not, at the moment, seem to have the ability to mount an effective takeover.
has remained in power under turbulent times for years now, despite new COVID19 threat

Venezuela was already in trouble before the Coronavirus epidemic, and they have responded like most South American countries-- very poorly. Venezuela is approaching a boiling point, and Maduro doesn't seem to have a lot of ways to turn down the heat.

Remains supported by China and Russia. COVID crisis is deepening in South America.
Activity of other countries (US, others in Americas) has decreased due to attention shifting to COVID.
Lowering but US might actively take him out now that he has been indicted on drug charges. A la Daniel Noriega.
Lowering. China and Russia support him. Even Guido has cooperated with him to raise money for anti-covid efforts.
Who will oust him? Too much on world plate to support a coup. He has more or less sustained a power base, the US has no strategic policy to follow through on it.

Maduro is going to charge more for gasoline. That ought to bring a round of outrage. If nothing happens from that and the US does not take some action to take him out then lowering. US now accusing Maduro’s wife of drug trafficking.

Going off of US actuarial tables [1], we'd predict a little under half a percent chance that a man of Maduro's age passes away in the coming year. Even assuming that he gets substantially better medical care than the average American or Venezuelan, head of state is a fairly risky job, so I'm happy bumping that up to a 1%. The CoupCast model from One Earth Future predicts a 1.8% chance of a coup in Venezuela this year [2] (assuming that we don't already count the Silvercorp, ah, incident). With the year already partially done, I'm happy blending that in in with other internal security risks to 2%, and I'm sure there are some things I haven't thought of, so I'd add a little fuzz factor. [1] https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
[2] https://oefresearch.org/activities/coup-cast
Continues to be a low probability event.
A baseline of 7% given the current situation. To be revised as the 2020 evolves.
Maduro has a strong, stubborn personality in the tradition of other so-called socialist leaders
Nobody's bothering him...there's always the risk of a coronavirus problem.
Too many other crises diverting attention from Venezuela.

Sanctions rarely hurt those in charge so they are unlikely to work here given this short time horizon. Much of the world is focused on COVID-19 so outside influences are likely lower than usual. The US is also focused on COVID-19,  along with, political/economic stability and an election cycle,  so it's hard to believe that there would be an overt attempt to remove Maduro. The covert, on the other hand, could derail this forecast.  And, considering an agreement to help with COVID-19 between Maduro's government and the opposition party; has he bought some time?

Maduro has stabilized his position. Street protests has died out, the economy was getting better in the last part of 2019 and he seem to have firm support from the police and military. This would put my confidence in him staying in power at 95%. The Venezuelan economy is to an extreme degree dependent on oil exports (which is 95% of all exports) and with a collapsed prize of oil the situation in the country will very likely lead to some kind of destabilization and maybe return of previous protests. Ending up at 80% likelihood of him continuing to be president for the rest of the year.
Forecasting for June was straight forward, for year end 2020 perhaps things will change for the better. His options may appear to be dwindeling.

My favorite heuristic (probably has a name) with something like this where there is virtually no useful base rate is to imagine the subject period of time playing out 10 or 20 times (for some reason that works better for my brain than the more logical 100 times), and imagine how many times the result in question played out. Right now my total gut is right around 1-in-10.   Running this heuristic backwards with the current crowd forecast  of 1-in-20, i.e.––"Does if seem reasonable that the next seven months, played out twenty times, would only result in one 'yes'?"––seems too low. Within the above, I'm thinking about many of the things folks mention below (sanctions, attempted coup, other factors both domestic and foreign), but I can't even begin to wrap my head around applying specific values/weights to those.  I'm fascinated to learn more about how very skilled forecasters approach this type of question.
strong men are hard to displace

Some dictators last forever, like Castro, but usually with very strong support from another nation willing to prop them up.  Russia is backing away and even China will  not be too generous.  When your financial support depends on the economy of Iran and Cuba your days may be counting down.  He is surrounded by opportunist whose loyalty will be to themselves.

Venezuela has about $4 Billion in gold and 25% of that is held in Bank of England who refuses to release it.  Burn rate is about one billion per year but I expect that it will increase as the pile dwindles down and providors of supplies raise prices.  Aside:  iran isn't helping venezuela, it's plundering what gold remains. I think he s secure for 2020.  I expect him to be gone in 2021. As long as sanctions remain and the us navy intercepts drugsand shipping to  Venezuela then it is just a matter of time. Money, you've got lots of friends
Crowding round the door
When you're gone and spending ends

I don't see any imminent threat to Maduro. Sure, there are the US sanctions and the international community tends to favor Juan Guaidó, but that alone is not going to make  Maduro to step down. Also, with the US elections happening this year. I really doubt Trump will send troops or anything like that.  This is one prediction I'd be extremely happy to be wrong about.

While there seem to be more sanctions coming [1] from the US against those supporting the oil sector, Maduro is making friends where he can find them and pulling Iran close [2]. Additionally, he is now embracing the opposition leader to team up and fight COVID. All this could change quickly, but where he has the US to easily scapegoat, especially with the botched coup attempt (even though they were unassisted by the US gov't directly), power won't be changing hands very soon. Things are pretty rocky now. Have to do more research but he could be out.
Maduro not stepping down if he doesn't want to. The question is, does he want to? And, if he wants to, say by reaching an agreement with Guaidó, will a power transition happen by the end of the year?
